abetting.gerund: encourage the perpetrator to commit an offence.

adversarial system.noun: a legal system where the two advocates represent their parties' case or position before an impartial person or group of people.

apeal.verb: apply to a higher court for a reversal of the decision of a lower court.

assault.note: This is a crime covered in section 265 of the Criminal Code

battery.noun: an offensive touching or use of force on a person without the person's consent.
battery.note: The battery crimial concept doesn't exist in Criminal Code. It is more of a term came from the States.

codified.noun: officially arrange a law to be discuss.

common law.noun: a system of law that relies on old court cases to decide for the current case and is common to all people.
common law.note: Developed in English courts around 10th century

conditional sentence.noun: a prison sentence that can be served in the community with strict terms attached.
conditional sentence.note: Section 718.2(e) of the Criminal Code specifically talk about this, also known as "alternative sentencing".

consent.noun: to agree voluntarily to an action.
consent.note: That person must be fully conscious, fully understand the action; in some case, they can withdraw the consent at any time.

conspiracy.noun: agreed to execute an illegal act, even if that act does not actually occur.
conspiracy.note: Just the agreement is enough to being convicted of a crime.

diplomatic immunity.noun: certain foreign government officials are recognized as having legal immunity from the jurisdiction of another country.
diplomatic immunity.note: This is a principle/convention rather than an actual laws. If this was violated, it may result in diplomatic problems than judicial issues.

extradition.noun: an action wherein one jurisdiction delivers a person accused or convicted of committing a crime in another jurisdiction, over to the other's law enforcement.
extradition.note: Extradition Act rules out all of the necessary steps over the process of extradition in Canada

fraud.noun: intentional deception to secure unfair or unlawful gain, or to deprive a victim of a legal right.
fraud.note: This crime was defined in section 380 of the Criminal Code.

habeas corpus.noun: prevent unlawful arrest by ensuring that anyone detained is brought before a court.
habeas corpus.note: Latin for "you must have a body"

indictment.noun: a formal accusation that a person has committed a crime.

inquisitorial system.noun: the trial judges are inquisitors who actively participate in fact-finding public inquiry by questioning defense lawyers, prosecutors, and witnesses.
inquisitorial system.note: France criminal justice system is using the inquisitorial system. Judges could even order certain pieces of evidence to be examined if they find presentation by the defense or prosecution to be inadequate.

jurisdiction.noun: the official power to make legal decisions and judgments.
jurisdiction.note: It also means the extent of the power to make legal decisions and judgments.

juvenile deliquents.noun: a young person who habitually commits criminal acts or offenses.
juvenile deliquents.age: Usuaully considered between 7 and 16 to 18, depends on the province.
juvenile deliquents.note: The Young Offenders Act handle all of the crimes commit by juveniles.

onus.noun: used to refer to something that is one's duty or responsibility.

open custody.a sentence: directing a youth to stay in a group home for a certain period.
open custody.note: This is a form of alternative sentencing, but only apply for youth offender.

perpetrator.noun: a person who carries out a harmful, illegal, or immoral act.

polygamy.noun: being married to more that one person at the same time.
polygamy.note: It is technically illegal, but there isn't any consequence except it can't be done on paper.

prejudice.noun: preconceived opinion based on a stereotype.

restitution.noun: the courts order the defendant to give up their gains to the claimant.
restitution.note: This is different from compensation because compensation is just paying for the loss suffered by the claimant. Meanwhile, restitution is seeking for the profit/gains that the defendant made by the wrongful act.

restribution.noun: justice based on punishment for wrongful acts.

Rule of Law.noun: the principle stating that all citizens within a country accountable to the same laws and not governedd by arbitrary power.

scab.noun: a slang name for a worker who crosses a picket line to work during a strike
scab.note: Why? It is their right! Okay I won't judge them...

sheriff.noun: court official responsible for jury management, including relay the information, instructing the jury, guide the jury.
sheriff.note: They however must try their best not the influence jurors' decision.

slaner.verb: make false and damaging statements about (someone).
slaner.noun: the action or crime of making a false spoken statement damaging to a person's reputation.

suspect.noun: a person thought to be guilty of a crime or offense.
suspect.verb: have an idea or impression of the existence, presence, or truth of (something) without certain proof.
suspect.note: This is mostly what the legal system usually refer to when considering someone of a crime.

tort.noun: a wrongful act or an infringement of a right (other than under contract) leading to civil legal liability.

trial by combat.phrase: two parties settle accusations by fighting in single combat; the winner of the fight was proclaimed to be right.

trial by ordeal.phrase: guilt or innocence of the accused was determined by subjecting them to a painful, or at least an unpleasant, usually dangerous experience.
trial by ordeal.note: "judgement of God": a procedure based on the premise that God would help the innocent by performing a miracle on their behalf.

trial by oath helping.phrase: requiring relatives of the accused to swear on the Bible that the accused is innocent.

writ.noun: formal written order issued by the court.
